thread.title: New Myer to raise $220m

author: Michael Roddan
title: New Myer to raise $220m
text:
BATTLING department store operator Myer is raising about $220 million to help fund a turnaround plan, after logging a dramatic decline in full-year profit.
The company today outlined a strategy that sets out around $600 million in proposed capital expenditure and implementation costs over five years.
Myer said the strategy would lead to a more productive store network with a smaller footprint, a restructuring of its store support office and a revamp of its online retailing channel.
“The New Myer strategy is built on providing a more focused and relevant merchandise offer to serve a more valuable customer and a better shopping experience for everyone who comes to our stores,” chief executive Richard Umbers said.
“The challenges facing the retail sector are well known, and we understand them deeply. Our strategic response to these issues defines a clear agenda for success.”
Myer also today posted a net profit after tax for the year to July 25 of $29.8 million, a 69.7 per cent slide over the previous year's $98.5 million profit.
The result was weighed down by the $24.5 million costs of closing its Top Ryde and Hurstville stores and other restructuring costs associated with the turnaround plan.
On an underlying basis, Myer's profit of $77.5 million was still a 21.3 per cent decline on last year's $98.5 million.
Total sales lifted 1.7 per cent over the year to $3.196 billion, while on a comparable stores basis, sales were up 1.1 per cent.
Myer declined to pay a dividend and said it intends to distribute shareholder returns following the first half of the 2016 financial year.
The retailer said it expects net profit after tax over the coming year to be between $64 million and $72 million, excluding restructuring costs, which are forecast at between $35 million and $45 million before tax.
Share offer to reduce debt, provide flexibility
The announced fully underwritten entitlement offer to retail and institutional investors aims to raise about $221 million at 94c per share. In the retail component, shareholders are entitled to two new shares for every five shares they hold.
The capital raising will be used to reduce core debt and provide balance sheet flexibility to implement the New Myer strategy.
The offer represents a 22 per cent discount on the stock’s last closing price. Myer shares were in a trading halt this morning following the announcement, and last traded at $1.21.
The polishing of the balance sheets follows a $600 million debt refinancing in June.
Mr Umbers has only been in the top job since March and recently appointed Grant Devonport as the group’s new chief financial officer as the retailer overhauls its business during a period of significant change within the industry.
The moves announced today were a significant step forward for Myer, he said.
“The board and management have taken prudent action to reset the balance sheet and add financial flexibility to the business,” Mr Umbers said.
In late June the retailer cut about 80 jobs from its head office amid a review of its current and future customer base, which formed the basis for its new strategy.
Myer said the five-year turnaround plan will be an “energetic revitalisation of Australia’s best-loved retailer”.
“The New Myer strategy is a sustainable business model that will enable us to maintain and improve our competitive position and return the business to sustainable profit growth in the coming years,” the company said.
The retailer is expecting to invest between $100 million and $120 million in the business over the coming fiscal year as it reallocates retail space from underperforming categories to new and higher performing lines.
Myer will also focus on a “narrower and more powerful range” of brands, along with a rollout of Wi-Fi and upgraded fitting rooms and restaurants, cafes and event spaces.
